page.title: 05MOSS VALLEY, ITS USE BY MAN
page.content: The Moss Valley runs from Coal Aston to Eckington where it joins the Rother. It is an outstanding example of a valley largely unaffectedd by 20th Century development. It does however have a long history of use by man. Once the valley was mainly wooded but by the 17th Century, clearances had created the mosaic we see today. At first the land was farmed but the discovery of iron in the 13th Century created an iron industry. Later on coal was found and this replaced wood for smalting, to produce high quality agricultural tools like sickles. These industries have now gone from the valley but they have left their mark with the remains of drift mines into the hillside and trackways used for transporting materials. Farming now dominates once more.
